course.subject: IELM
course.name: Engineering Probability and Statistics
course.description: This is a systematic introduction to basic probability theory and statistics for engineering, including data collection and analysis, sample space and sampling methods, calculus of probability, conditional probability, expectation, moments, discrete and continuous probability distributions, point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing and linear regression analysis.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1003 OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1018 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024
course.exclusions: ISOM 2500, LIFS 3150, MATH 2411, MATH 2421

reviews.author: j217
reviews.title: Self-study course
reviews.comment_content:
Quite of a lot of content. Difficult for beginners to understand. The notes are poorly written with insufficient and irrelevant examples.
You need to study by yourself in order to understand what's going on. :(
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is a SELF-STUDY course. Do not expect any effective lectures or notes.
I would say that this lecturer doesn't know how to teach.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (25%): mean
Final (45%): below half a s.d.
Group Project(18%)
Homework(12%)
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment per week. (Most answers can be found online)
A 2-sided project.
Acceptable workload but the assignments are not that useful to help you understand the concepts.

reviews.author: whoDis
reviews.title: IELM 2510
reviews.comment_content:
This course has some stimulating topics and problems in probability and statistics you might enjoy working on. The difficulty of this course lies in understanding the very concepts and the conditions that makes them valid, this becomes essential in story problems (which are the vast majority of those you'd encounter).

Prof. Jiheng did not recommend a specific book, but it would help to find one that covers the following topics to organize your studies.

Course's Outline:

Module I: Sample Spaces and Events, conditioning, Bayes' formula, and independent events.  
Module II-a: Discrete Random Variables.
Module II-b: Continuous Random Variables.
++Midterm Exam++

Module II-c: Joint Distribution and Covariance.
Module III: Sample Mean and Variance, Law of Large Numbers, and the Central Limit Theorem.
Module IV: Descriptive Statistics.
Module V:  Parameter Estimation.
Module VI: Hypothesis Testing.
Module VII: Regression.
++End of Year Exam+
reviews.comment_teaching: You can easily see how Prof. Jiheng is very into the course he teaches. Unlike other professors, his English is very easily understood and he is able to convey the concepts clearly. He is understanding too.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading of this course is very forgiving. There is a one-page project on statistical inference which you can choose to either do it individually or in a group of no more than 4 people.  
No attendance is taken.

Assessment:
Weekly Assignments     18%
Midterm Exam               25%
Final Exam                    45%
Mini-Project                   12%

Personally:
Assignments:   My Mean: 9.6/10      Class Overall Mean: 9.3/10
Midterm Exam:  85/100 (curved)
Final Exam and Mini-Project grades are not published

Final Grade:  A
reviews.comment_workload:
Keep in mind this is a 4-credits course. I'd say that if you are aiming for A range, you should:
1- Be able to do every single question (or alternative form) appearing in the lecture and tutorial notes as well as in the assignments - not by memorizing the steps for sure.
2- Understand the most famous problems and paradigms in probability, e.g: Monty Hall problem, Prisoner's dilemma, Boy or Girl paradox, etc.

reviews.author: Shree
reviews.comment_content:
The course content consists of two parts; probability and stats.
It covers all the basis elements of probability (conditional, bayes theorem), random variables, limiting theorems, statistics, hypothesis testing and regression analysis.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has been involved with this course for quite a while and that's easily evident with the way he teaches the course and coherently resolves the questions in class. He's loud and clear unlike some of the other IELM profs and there's absolutely no issues in deciphering his accent.
reviews.comment_grading:
10 homeworks + 1 project
1 Midterm and a final examination.
(one double-sided cheat sheet allowed for the exams)

Project 12%, Hw 18%, Midterm 25%, final 45%

The grading of the course is pretty decent and exciting; the mean is usually set around B+ and it isn't difficult to get a good grade if you put in some efforts
reviews.comment_workload:
The course has weekly assignments starting off right from week 2 until the last week with the difficulty level increasing linearly.

In total there are 10 homeworks, a midterm, a final and a project.
Final exam is cumulative.

Project is group based and isn't demanding if the group members decide to contribute in at least some amount.

All the workload pretty much gets compensated towards the end with a pleasing course grade.

reviews.title: Stat and probi

reviews.author: legendarychriz
reviews.title: Worst lecturer i have met in my uni life
reviews.comment_content: In order to know what is going on about IELM, this course will show you how probability is related to it. Such as calculating the possibilities of success/failure, and allow you to make decisions after calculations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She just used all the notes from Jiheng Zhang, and I was expecting something new. Unable to clear the concepts of probability and unable guide us through the homework. There is such a  gap between homework and lecture notes.
I strongly recommend you to self-study.
reviews.comment_grading:
Make sure the concept of probability is clear, such as the usage of each methods, so it will be easier for you to catch up in midterm or finals.

Midterm: 62/100 below mean about 3 marks
Final: 47/100, below mean about 0.4 sd
Project contains about 12% marks, but the score is unknown.

B- is the grade that a get, which i consider it  rather good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Compared with other 4 credit course, it is relatively light.
Only project with one 2-sided paper, and homework every week. Workload can be even less then a 3 credit course.

reviews.author: 5M5
reviews.comment_content:
Tentative Course Outline:
1. Elements of Probability
• Sample space and events • Axioms of probability • Conditional probability • Bayes rule • Independence
2. Random Variables
• Discrete random variables • Continuous random variables • Joint distribution and covariance
3. Limiting Theorems
• Law of large numbers • Central limit theorems
4. Descriptive Statistics
• Frequency tables and graphs, histograms, leaf plots, • Sample mean and variance, sample median, sample percentile • Chebyshev’s inequality for data
5. Parameter Estimation
• Maximum likelihood estimators • Interval estimates • Conﬁdence intervals
6. Hypothesis Testing
• Signiﬁcance levels, • Various tests
7. Regression Analysis
• Least square estimators, • Distribution of estimators, • Statistical inference
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. ZHANG is very nice and friendly. He teaches very well, too.
reviews.comment_grading:
midterm (25%), ﬁnal (45%), homework (18%), project (12%).
Very good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Reasonable. Remember it is a 4 credits course.

reviews.author: Plasticsmile
reviews.comment_content:
Probability (Axioms, Conditional probability, Independence...); Random Variables; Limiting Theorems; Descriptive Statistics; Parameter Estimation; Hypothesis Testing; Regression Analysis

Difficult but useful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Clear explanation in the video. The videos show all the calculation steps and have some examples inside.
You can ask many questions as you can in the lecture coz it's how the lecture works.
Watch video --> Go to the lecture --> Ask question
reviews.comment_grading:
test I (12%), test II (24%), ﬁnal (34%), homework (18%), project (12%)
Really, really low mean, but B range for mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
You need to watch videos before lecture, otherwise you won't understand what the professor is taking about.
One homework every week, not easy, need to spend quite a long time on it if you really do it by yourself ;)
Need to decide your own topic for the group project, not difficult at all. Only some groups need to present (lucky draw / self-recommandation).

reviews.author: Vincent Wen
reviews.title: Engineering Statistics and Probability
reviews.comment_content: Very useful and practical in the engineering field. And many industrial engineering courses are based on the knowledge he taught
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof is a nice person and is always willing to answer any questions raised by students
reviews.comment_grading: Absolutely good grade, but the a range seems to be 15%.
reviews.comment_workload: Intermediate workload for a weekly hand-written homework, but the final group project is not well designed especially for the time period. It happened in the final exam period and cost time which was able to use to review other courses
